intro: Chrysanthemum grubovii, commonly known as the Armenian chrysanthemum, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Armenia and Turkey. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and serrated leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring daisy-like yellow flowers that bloom in late summer to early autumn. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade, making it suitable for rock gardens and alpine settings. Due to its ornamental value and limited distribution, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
